graphicalElements.text: Two men come into the pub at 5pm and start drinking heavily. They begin consuming a large amount of alcohol very quickly. This goes on for about 2 hours. At this point what do you do?
Customers don't like being 'bluntly' told their service is being "cut-off"! Use a more professional, diplomatic approach to avoid sounding arrogant, authoritarian and a potential escalation.
You're friendly yet assertive, which is very appropriate at this point. Applying a good, professional intervention strategy to minimise harm.
This response shows a good effort. To improve your approach, try diplomatically explaining why you have suggested they slow down their drinking.
The general message is in your dialogue. However, if you provide valid reason to this, you can maintain a calm situation.

Here you sound very abrupt. To prevent undesired reactions, try to show more empathy, use also your facial expressions and stance to support your message. Also, ensure you explain the reason without 'judgement'.
Great! You've convinced the customer! You were polite, professional and empathetic - It sounds like you are genuinely considering their well being!
You made it clear this is going to be the "last round". So the customers are aware. Though, with a bit more diplomacy and tactic you could avoid customers becoming agitated and indignant.
Try to be more empathetic, diplomatic and respectful when communicating reasons for refusing service. Customers are more likely to be understanding, which helps prevent further escalation.
A well-delivered message and appropriate action that follows the law. This is a very successful outcome!
